stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the final main level, Course 15. He refines the boss fight, walks through the spaceship interior sub-area, and then pivots the boss arena design based on community feedback. He also plans the layout and content for a 'retro section' based on Super Mario 64, sourcing the original level geometry.

development_findings.summary: The team is on the verge of completing the last of the 15 main courses, after which development will shift to polishing content.
development_findings.quote: Oh my God, dude, all the main courses will be finished. That will feel so good.

development_findings.summary: The Course 15 boss, a mutated Yoshi, was originally designed with grotesque tumors, but they were changed to mushrooms to make the design less 'traumatizing'.
development_findings.quote: At first I had him grow tumors. And I showed this to someone and they said this is way too disgusting. So I changed the tumors into mushrooms.

development_findings.summary: The boss arena for Course 15 was changed mid-stream from a complex factory to a destructible planet, a suggestion from Biobak that Kaze deemed cooler and more efficient.
A 'retro section' is being designed as a tribute to Super Mario 64, combining iconic segments from the original 15 courses into a single platforming challenge.
Ongoing changes to the game's core engine and microcode cause older, completed levels to break, creating a backlog of fixes required during the polishing phase.
development_findings.quote: This is what happens when you keep changing the engine, all the levels just break.

development_findings.summary: The game's current ROM size is 58.8MB, which fits comfortably within the self-imposed 64MB limit of an N64 cartridge.
Kaze is still conceptualizing the final boss, suggesting it should be what the enslaved Yoshis were forced to build for Bowser, but the idea is not yet concrete.
Kaze identified and needs to fix a critical bug where performing a Backwards Long Jump (BLJ) can crash the game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design philosophy against adding excessive gameplay options, believing it creates a bloated, confusing experience and is a waste of development resources.
context_findings.quote: People always ask for more and more and if I added everyone's request for options, I would have an option menu with 260 items and it would be shit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is balancing the intense development schedule with his personal life, including his parents visiting to see his new baby.
context_findings.quote: Dude, I'm just so fucking busy. I generally just do not have time to do anything.

context_findings.summary: The project has incorporated guest level designers, Hazer and Martiste, who are contributing side levels.
Kaze employs a design principle of showing players a desirable goal (like a star) early on that they cannot yet reach, in order to build anticipation and motivation.
context_findings.quote: I've come to realize that it's very important to constantly edge the player.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels he has processed the most valuable feedback from the public demo and finds that new feedback is often contradictory or overly nitpicky.
Kaze has hired someone to create YouTube shorts for his channel for $5 each, which he finds hilarious despite their 'cringe' mobile-ad style.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided the pivotal suggestion to change the Course 15 boss arena from a generic factory to a destructible planet, which Kaze immediately adopted.
biobak.quote: That's a cool idea. That is a very cool idea.

biobak.summary: Kaze is waiting for Biobak to finalize the boss model before fully implementing it, indicating an iterative design process between them.
Kaze acknowledges Biobak's superior artistic skill, specifically mentioning his own 'sucky' UV mapping on a spaceship model.
biobak.quote: I know Biobak. I'm still a newbie artist, you know how it is.

badub.summary: Kaze is looking forward to what Badub will compose for the Mario 64 retro section, anticipating a potential mashup of classic themes.

zeina.summary: Zeina is animating the 'baby Yoshi' enemies that are spawned during the Course 15 boss fight.
zeina.quote: Zayna's currently animating them. So hopefully they will be better once they are animated.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentioned discussing demo feedback with Zeina, indicating her involvement in higher-level design and player experience discussions.

key_stories.title: The Planet Boss Arena Pivot
key_stories.summary: During the stream, Kaze was working on a factory-themed boss arena. Artist Biobak suggested making it a planet that the boss destroys instead. Kaze loved the idea and immediately pivoted the design, abandoning the factory for the cooler, more efficient planet concept.
key_stories.challenge: The initial design for the Course 15 boss arena was a complex, high-poly factory that Kaze was not fully satisfied with.
key_stories.process: While streaming, team member Biobak suggested an alternative: having the boss fight take place on a planet that the boss destroys at the start of the fight. Kaze immediately latched onto the idea, brainstorming how the destruction effect could work and recognizing its benefits.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to completely discard the factory concept in favor of the destructible planet arena, praising it as a superior idea that was both cooler and more technically efficient.
key_stories.key_quote: That would also be lower poly than my whole stupid factory here. And I hate that I have this whole factory here actually.

key_stories.title: Recovering the SM64 Geometry
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed old SM64 level files for a new area, but they were in an unusable format. After a comical failure with an online converter, a community member on Discord converted the files for him live on stream, allowing development to proceed.
key_stories.challenge: To build the 'retro section,' Kaze needed the original level geometry from Super Mario 64. He found his old files from a 2018 project, but they were in the proprietary .skp (Sketchup) format, which he couldn't use.
key_stories.process: Kaze expressed frustration at not wanting to install Sketchup. He tried a free online file converter, which failed comically after making him play a slow game of Tetris. He then reached out to his community on Discord, and a user named HooliKaleb offered to convert the files for him.
key_stories.outcome: A community member successfully converted the .skp files to a usable format and sent them back to Kaze during the stream, unblocking his progress and allowing him to begin planning the retro level's layout.
key_stories.key_quote: You're kidding me, I did Tetris for nothing?

key_stories.title: The Philosophy of No Options
key_stories.summary: When a viewer asked for an option to use vanilla physics, Kaze explained his strong design philosophy against adding excessive options. He believes it creates a worse player experience and is a waste of development effort, cementing his vision for a single, polished version of the game.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer requested an option to switch back to vanilla Mario 64 physics, disagreeing with the new movement system in RTYI.
key_stories.process: Kaze firmly rejected the idea, explaining his design philosophy that adding options for every preference leads to bloated menus and is an immense waste of development time that could be spent improving the core game.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze established his clear design principle: he is building a specific, curated experience, not a sandbox of customizable features. He confirmed he will not be adding difficulty modes or extensive control options.
key_stories.key_quote: There's one thing where I will consistently disagree with the people asking for stuff and that is options.
